TETRACOSACTIDE

  • Indications and doses
  • Pregnancy
  • Hepatic impairment
  • Renal impairment
  • Contra indications
  • Side effects
  • Cautions
  • Effect on laboratory tests
  • Allergy and cross sensitivity
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Diagnosis of adrenocortical insufficiency (diagnostic 30-minute test),

By intravenous injection or by intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    250 micrograms for 1 dose.

Diagnosis of adrenocortical insufficiency (diagnostic 5-hour test),

By intramuscular injection using depot injection

  • For adults
    1 mg for 1 dose.

Alternative to corticosteroids in conditions such as Crohn's disease or rheumatoid arthritis (formerly used but value was limited by the variable and unpredictable therapeutic response and by the waning of effect with time),

Initially by intramuscular injection using depot injection

  • For adults
    Initially 1 mg daily, alternatively (by intramuscular injection) initially 1 mg every 12 hours, (in acute cases), then (by intramuscular injection) reduced to 1 mg every 2–3 days, followed by (by intramuscular injection) 1 mg once weekly, alternatively (by intramuscular injection) 500 micrograms every 2–3 days.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Avoid (but may be used diagnostically if essential).

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

An enhanced effect of tetracosactide therapy may occur in patients with cirrhosis of the liver.

Use with caution in hepatic impairment.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Use with caution in patients with renal impairment.

Contra indications

  • Acute psychosis
  • adrenogenital syndrome
  • allergic disorders
  • asthma
  • avoid injections containing benzyl alcohol in neonates
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • infectious diseases
  • peptic ulcer
  • primary adrenocortical insufficiency
  • refractory heart failure

Known side effects

General side effects

notKnown: Abdominal distention, abscess, acne, anaphylactic shock, angioneurotic oedema, aseptic necrosis of femoral and humeral heads, benign intracranial pressure increased with papilloedema, calcium deficiency, cardiac disorders, convulsions, Cushing's syndrome, decreased carbohydrate tolerance, dizziness, dysponea, ecchymosis, erythema, euphoria, fluid retention, flushing, glaucoma, growth retardation, headache, hirsutism, hyperglycaemia, hyperhidrosis, hypersensitivity reactions (tend to be more severe in patients susceptible to allergies, especially asthma), hypertension, hypokalaemia, hypokalaemic alkalosis, impaired healing, increased appetite, increased intraocular pressure, infection susceptibility increased, insomnia, irregular menstruation, leukocytosis, malaise, manifestations of latent diabetes mellitus, mood swings, muscle atrophy, muscular weakness, myopathy, nausea, necrotising vasculitis, negative nitrogen balance, osteoporosis, pancreatitis, pathological fracture of long bones, peptic ulcer, personality changes, petechiae, posterior subcapsular cataracts, pruritis, psychotic manifestations, Quincke's oedema, secondary adrenocortical unresponsiveness, secondary pituitary unresponsiveness, severe depression, skin atrophy, skin hyperpigmentation, skin reactions at injection site, sodium retention, spinal compression fractures, tendon rupture, thromboembolism, ulcerative oesophagitis, urticaria, vertigo, vomiting, weight increase,

Cautions regarding administration

  • Active infectious diseases (should not be used unless adequate disease-specific therapy is being given)
  • active systemic diseases (should not be used unless adequate disease-specific therapy is being given)
  • diabetes mellitus
  • diverticulitis
  • history of asthma
  • history of atopic allergy
  • history of eczema
  • history of hayfever
  • history of hypersensitivity
  • hypertension
  • latent amoebiasis (may become activated)
  • latent tuberculosis (may become activated)
  • myasthenia gravis
  • ocular herpes simplex
  • osteoporosis
  • predisposition to thromboembolic
  • pscyhological disturbances may be triggered
  • recent intestinal anastomosis
  • reduced immune response (should not be used unless adequate disease-specific therapy is being given)
  • ulcerative colitis

  • Should only be administered under medical supervision.

    Consult product literature.

  • Patients already receiving medication for moderate to severe hypertension must have their dosage adjusted if treatment started.

  • Patients already receiving medication for diabetes mellitus must have their dosage adjusted if treatment started.

Effect on laboratory tests

May suppress skin test reactions.

Post administration total plasma cortisol levels during 30-minute test for diagnosis of adrenocotical insufficiency might be misleading due to altered cortisol binding globulin levels in some special clinical situations including, patients on oral contraceptives, post-operative patients, critical illness, severe liver disease and nephrotic syndrome.

Advice regarding allergies and cross sensitivities

Contraindicated in patients with history of hypersensitivity to tetracosactide/corticotrophins or excipients.

Prepared medicinal forms of TETRACOSACTIDE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Solution for injection
Suspension for injection
